user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_init_page_sizes:
```c
static int metal_init_page_sizes(void)
{
	const int max_sizes = MAX_PAGE_SIZES - 1;
	long sizes[max_sizes];

	/* Determine system page size. */
	sizes[0] = getpagesize();
	if (sizes[0] <= 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to get page size\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	_metal.page_size  = sizes[0];
	_metal.page_shift = metal_log2(sizes[0]);
	metal_add_page_size(_metal.tmp_path, _metal.page_shift, 0);

#ifdef HAVE_HUGETLBFS_H
#ifndef MAP_HUGE_SHIFT
	/* System does not support multiple huge page sizes. */
	sizes[0] = gethugepagesize();
	if (sizes[0] > 0) {
		metal_add_page_size(hugetlbfs_find_path(),
				    metal_log2(sizes[0]),
				    MAP_HUGETLB);
	}
#else
	if (gethugepagesize() >= 0) {
		int i, count;

		/* System supports multiple huge page sizes. */
		count = gethugepagesizes(sizes, max_sizes);
		for (i = 0; i < count; i++) {
			int shift = metal_log2(sizes[i]);

			if ((shift & MAP_HUGE_MASK) != shift)
				continue;
			metal_add_page_size(
				hugetlbfs_find_path_for_size(sizes[i]),
				shift, (MAP_HUGETLB |
				(shift << MAP_HUGE_SHIFT)));
		}
	}
#endif
#endif

	/* Finally sort the resulting array by size. */
	qsort(_metal.page_sizes, _metal.num_page_sizes,
	      sizeof(struct metal_page_size), metal_pagesize_compare);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_init_page_sizes:
#define MAX_PAGE_SIZES 32
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
...
static int metal_add_page_size(const char *path, int shift, int mmap_flags)
{
	int index = _metal.num_page_sizes;
	unsigned long size = 1UL << shift;

	if (index >= MAX_PAGE_SIZES) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "skipped page size %ld - overflow\n",
			  size);
		return -EOVERFLOW;
	}

	if (!path || shift <= 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "skipped page size %ld - invalid args\n",
			  size);
		return -EINVAL;
	}

	_metal.page_sizes[index].page_shift = shift;
	_metal.page_sizes[index].page_size = size;
	_metal.page_sizes[index].mmap_flags = mmap_flags;
	strncpy(_metal.page_sizes[index].path, path, PATH_MAX);
	_metal.num_page_sizes++;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "added page size %ld @%s\n", size, path);

	return 0;
}
...
static int metal_pagesize_compare(const void *_a, const void *_b)
{
	const struct metal_page_size *a = _a, *b = _b;
	long diff = a->page_size - b->page_size;

	return metal_sign(diff);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected the fragments related to hugepage handling because they are conditional on platform headers/macros and on the return values/types of gethugepagesize/gethugepagesizes and on the values of MAP_HUGE_MASK and MAP_HUGE_SHIFT; those conditions can make portions of those blocks unreachable in a given build or at runtime and therefore warrant investigation for Rule 2.1. I did not mark other code as suspicious because:
- The initial system page-size retrieval and the early return (sizes[0] = getpagesize(); if (sizes[0] <= 0) { ... return; }) are straightforward runtime checks that make the remainder reachable only when appropriate; they are not statically unreachable.
- Assignments to _metal.page_size/_metal.page_shift, the call to metal_add_page_size(_metal.tmp_path,...), and the final qsort call are reachable whenever the function continues past the early return and are normal control flow (no obvious always-false or always-true compile-time conditions present in the shown code).
- Calls to metal_add_page_size() and metal_log() perform runtime checks and may return early internally, but that does not create statically unreachable code in this function.
- Preprocessor-guarded code that is excluded when macros are not defined is not included here because whether it is compiled depends on build configuration; where such guarded code exists (the hugepage block) I included the relevant fragments for investigation.
If you provide the build configuration (defined macros) and signatures/return types for gethugepagesize/gethugepagesizes and MAP_HUGE_* macros, I can refine the analysis and mark any definitely unreachable lines more precisely.
